On Sat, Dec 4, 2010 at 10:28 AM, Eric J. Bowman <eric@...> wro=
te:
> Peter Williams wrote:
>>
>> >
>> > Just a terminology nitpick: =A0not=
hing that isn't in the registry is a
>> > media type.
>>
>> I respectfully =
disagree. =A0I phrased it the way i did on purpose.
>>
>
> The pertinent RF=
Cs only use the term "media type" in reference to
> values registered in th=
e standards, vendor and personal trees. =A0The
> term "type" is used in ref=
erence to the x. and x- non-trees. =A0The term
> "access type" is used in r=
eference to things which could become media
> types. =A0REST uses the term =
"data type" in reference to the specs
> targeted by a media type.

I use th=
e term in the spirit of the dissertation.  "The data format of
a representa=
tion is known as a media type" (para 5, section 5.2.1.2).
A car that is not=
 registered with the local authorities is still a
car, it just not legal to=
 drive it on the public roads.  Same with
media types.  A data format that =
is not registered with iana is still
a media type, it is just not technical=
ly legal to use it via http on
the public internet.

Peter
